facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 974 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 974 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 10, 1964 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 113 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1964, of the High Court in Madhya Pradesh in Misc. Petition No. 113 of 1964. up.165-8

facts.text: Material facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court the question which arises for decision is whether the assessment list of house tax and companyservancy tax companyfirmed by the Municipal Council,

facts.text: On December 28, 1962, Municipal Council by resolution appointed Sub-Committee consisting of Vice-President and two Members for hearing objections under S. 138(2).

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are number in dispute. On December 28, 1962 the Municipal Council by a resolution, appointed a Sub- Committee companysisting of the Vice-President and two Members for hearing objections under S. 138 2  of the Act

facts.text: On December 30, 1962, Chief Municipal Officer directed to prepare assessment lists for all 11 wards.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th of that month the Chief Municipal Officer was directed to prepare the assessment lists for all the 11 words into which the municipal area has been divided.

facts.text: Prior to that, taxes levied at Rs. 7-12-0 per cent on annual letting value of house properties and building sites.

anchor.surface_text: Up till then taxes were levied at the rate of Rs. 7-12-0 per cent. on the annual letting value of the house properties and building sites liable to be taxed.

facts.text: On March 3, 1963, Council considered proposal for slab system; Smt. Poonabai's modification accepted by majority.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1963 the Council companysidered a proposal for introducing a slab system for assessing these proper-ties. Upon that one of the members, Smt. Poonabai suggested a modification

facts.text: On March 6, 1963, assessment list prepared by Chief Municipal Officer authenticated and published under s.136; objections invited; about 2200 objections lodged.

anchor.surface_text: On March 6, 1963 the assessment list prepared by the Chief Municipal Officer in pursuance of the resolution was authenticated by him. It was then duly published that day under s. 136 of the Act.

facts.text: Sub-Committee considered 2200 objections between April 7 and April 14, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: About 2,200 objections were lodged which were companysidered by the Sub-Committee between April 7, 1963 and April 14, 1963.

facts.text: Suit instituted by some assessees challenging validity of March 3, 1963 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile it would appear that a suit had been instituted by some of the assessees in which the validity of the resolution of March 3, 1963 varying the rate of tax

facts.text: On April 28, 1963, Council revoked March 3, 1963 resolution and reverted to old rate.

anchor.surface_text: That meeting was held on April 28, 1963 and there the resolution of March 3, 1963 was revoked and the old rate of assessment was reverted to.

facts.text: Complaints by assessees that Sub-Committee showed partiality, favour to rich persons.

anchor.surface_text: Numerous companyplaints were made by assessees to the effect that the Sub-Committee had shown partiality in dealing with objections to assessments and had in fact shown favour to rich persons.

facts.text: President inquired into complaints and was satisfied there was substance.

anchor.surface_text: The President of the Council enquired into the companyplaints and was satisfied that there was substance in them.

facts.text: On August 21, 1963, Sub-Committee decision led to authentication of revised list under s.140, published August 30, 1963; demand notices issued.

anchor.surface_text: pursuant to a decision of the Sub-Committee dated August 21, 1963 the assessment list as revised by the Sub-Committee was authenticated by the Chief Municipal Officer as required by s. 140

facts.text: On October 9, 1963, Collector suspended execution of Sub-Committee decision under s.323.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1963 the Collector made the following order In exercise of the powers delegated to me under section 323 of the M.P. Municipalities Act, 1961 I hereby suspend

facts.text: Collector forwarded order to Government for confirmation under s.323(2).

anchor.surface_text: He forwarded a companyy of the order to the Government of Madhya Pradesh and requested that his Order may be companyfirmed under s. 323  2  of the Act.

facts.text: President proclaimed suspension of assessment list and advised assessees not to pay taxes on revised list.

anchor.surface_text: After receiving this companymunication the President caused a proclamation to be made bringing it to the numberice of the assessees that the assessment list had been suspended

facts.text: On December 2, 1963, Government issued notice to Council under s.323(2) to show cause why Collector's order should not be confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, acting upon the companymunication received from the Collector issued numberice to the Council on December 2, 1963 under s. 323 2  to show cause

facts.text: Government confirmed Collector's order.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually the Government companyfirmed the Collectors Order.

facts.text: On December 29, 1963, Council at special meeting resolved to revise assessment lists under s.141.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1963 the Council, at a special meeting, resolved that the assessment lists should be revised under s. 141 ,of the Act.

facts.text: On January 7, 1964, Council issued notices to 300 persons to show cause why annual letting value should not be enhanced.

anchor.surface_text: On January 7, 1964 the Council issued individual numberices to 300 persons to show cause why the annual letting value of their properties should number be enhanced.

facts.text: Council heard objections from February 16 to 20, 1964 and revised assessments of some or all of the 300 persons.

anchor.surface_text: The Council heard the objections between February 16, 1964 and February 20, 1964 and revised the assessments of some or all the persons to whom numberices had been issued.

facts.text: On February 24, 1964, Council at special meeting confirmed revised assessment from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On February 24, 1964 the Council, at a special meeting, companyfirmed the revised assessment as from April 1, 1963.

facts.text: On March 4, 1964, resolution authenticated under s.140(1) by Chief Municipal Officer; list became final according to Council.

anchor.surface_text: Its resolution was authenticated on March 4, 1964 under s. 140 1  by the Chief Municipal Officer and according to the Council the assessment list then became final.

facts.text: Writ petition filed by some assessees before High Court challenging the assessment list.

anchor.surface_text: It is after this that the writ petition out of which the present appeal arises was presented before the High Court by some of the assessees.

facts.text: High Court quashed assessment list on ground that notices given only to 300 assessees, not remaining 1900.

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court the assessment list which had been companyfirmed by the Council on February 24, 1964 and sought to be given effect to was number a valid assessment list

facts.text: Procedure under ss.134,135,136 duly followed; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us that the procedure laid down in ss. 134, 135 and 136 of the Act for the assessment of buildings and lands to pay the tax was duly followed.

Amongst those particulars are the following Valuation of the property based on capital or annual letting value, as the case may be, on which the property is assessed  2  the rate, of tax applicable  3  the amount of tax assessed thereon.

arguments.claim: Under Art.265, tax liability procedure must be strictly complied with; objections based on published list with revoked rates not proper opportunity under s.137.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 265 of the Constitution numbertax shall be levied or companylected except by authority of law. This clearly implies that the procedure for imposing the liability to pay a tax has to be strictly companyplied with. Where it is number so companyplied with the liability to pay the tax cannot be said to be according to law. The objections which the assessees had filed in pursuance of the numberification actually published by the Chief Municipal Officer were based upon the list published under s. 136 and number in pursuance of what the liability would be under the Resolution of the Municipal Council, dated April 28, 1963. Therefore, it cannot he said that the opportunity as companytemplated by the Act was at all given to the assessees for lodging their objections as required by s. 137 of the Act.

arguments.claim: s.78 does not permit delegation of hearing/deciding objections to Sub-Committee.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, Mr. Setalvad was number able to point out to us any provision of the Act or of the rules, except s. 78, whereunder the Council companyld delegate its function of hearing and deciding objections to a Sub-Committee. Section 78 reads thus Any powers or duties or executive functions which may be exercised or performed by or on behalf of the Council may, in accordance with the rules made under this Act, be delegated by the Council to the President or Vice-President or to the Chairman of the Standing or other Committees, or to one or more stipendiary or honorary officers, but without prejudice to any powers that may have been companyferred on the Chief Municipal Officer by or under section 92.

holdings.text: The High Court properly exercised its discretion under Article 226 to entertain the writ petition despite availability of alternative remedy as no arbitrariness is shown.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court would not ordinarily entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution where an alternative remedy is open to the aggrieved party. Though that is so the High Court has jurisdiction to grant relief to such a party if it thinks proper to do so in the circumstances of the case. In the present case the High Court has chosen to exercise discretion in favour of the respondents and it would not be right for us to interfere with the exercise of that discretion unless we are satisfied that the action of the High Court was arbitrary or unreasonable. Nothing has been brought to our notice from which it could be inferred that the High Court acted arbitrarily in granting the writ prayed for to the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court jurisdiction exists despite alternative remedy; discretion exercised properly without arbitrariness.

holdings.text: The assessment list published under s.136 must contain full and accurate particulars specified in s.134(1), including valuation, rate of tax, and amount of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment list which has to be published under s. 136 of the Act must contain full and accurate particulars specified in s. 134 1  of the Act. Amongst those particulars are the following Valuation of the property based on capital or annual letting value, as the case may be, on which the property is assessed  2  the rate, of tax applicable  3  the amount of tax assessed thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory textual interpretation of ss.134(1) and 136 requiring accurate particulars in published list.

holdings.text: Since the list was published based on revoked March 3, 1963 resolution, the rate and tax particulars were inaccurate, violating strict procedural compliance under Art.265.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the resolution of March 3, 1963 on the basis of which the list was published had been revoked, the particulars mentioned in the second and the third of the above items would necessarily be different from those which would be arrived at after taking into account the resolution of April 28, 1963.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revocation changed applicable rates; published list inaccurate, breaching constitutional requirement for authority of law.

holdings.text: Objections lodged based on inaccurate published list did not provide opportunity contemplated by s.137, as not reflecting actual liability under April 28, 1963 resolution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.265 mandates strict procedure; objections on wrong basis fail audi alteram partem.

anchor.surface_text: ion. It is true that the High Court would number ordinarily entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution where an alternative remedy is ope

edges.explanation: Holding span overlaps issue span, addressing propriety of High Court entertaining petition under Art. 226 despite alternative remedy.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court would not ordinarily entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution where an alternative remedy is open to the aggrieved party. Though that is so the High Court has jurisdiction to grant relief to such a party if it thinks proper to do so in the circumstances of the case. In the present case the High Court has chosen to exercise discretion in favour of the respondents and it would not be right for us to interfere with the exercise of that discretion unless we are satisfied that the action of the High Court was arbitrary or unreasonable. Nothing has been brought to our notice from which it could be inferred that the High Court acted arbitrarily in granting the writ prayed for to the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the grounds are substantial and strike at the very root of the finality of the assessment list which was purported to be authenticated by the Chief Municipal Officer under s. The assessment list which has to be published under s. 136 of the Act must contain full and accurate particulars specified in s. 134 1  of the Act. [...] For these reasons we are of opinion that the assessment list authenticated by the Chief Municipal Officer was not prepared according to law and, therefore, the provisions of s. 141 were not available to the Council.
